articles.headline: Young Sheldon, Meet SpongeBob: CBS and Viacom Are Back Together
articles.snippet: Shari Redstone gets her wish, bringing about the merger of two media giants in a $25 billion deal. The plan is to become a content arms dealer in the streaming wars.
articles.abstract: Shari Redstone gets her wish, bringing about the merger of two media giants in a $25 billion deal. The plan is to become a content arms dealer in the streaming wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than a decade apart, CBS and Viacom are reuniting.

articles.headline: Trump Blocked Key Impeachment Witnesses. Should Congress Wait?
articles.snippet: At the first House Judiciary Committee impeachment hearing, Republicans’ witness said lawmakers were rushing the process and should instead let court fights over access to witnesses play out.
articles.abstract: At the first House Judiciary Committee impeachment hearing, Republicans’ witness said lawmakers were rushing the process and should instead let court fights over access to witnesses play out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Are House Democrats making a mistake by moving swiftly to impeach President Trump when some facts remain hidden about whether he abused his power in the Ukraine affair?

articles.headline: Scholars Call Trump’s Actions on Ukraine an Impeachable Abuse of Power
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans clashed over the Constitution and President Trump’s conduct as the House Judiciary Committee formally began its impeachment proceedings.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans clashed over the Constitution and President Trump’s conduct as the House Judiciary Committee formally began its impeachment proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives on Wednesday opened a critical new phase of the impeachment proceedings against President Trump, featuring legal scholars vigorously debating whether his conduct and the available evidence rose to the constitutional threshold necessary for his removal from office.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: What the C.I.A.’s Torture Program Looked Like to the Tortured
articles.snippet: Drawings done in captivity by the first prisoner known to undergo “enhanced interrogation” portray his account of what happened to him in vivid and disturbing ways.
articles.abstract: Drawings done in captivity by the first prisoner known to undergo “enhanced interrogation” portray his account of what happened to him in vivid and disturbing ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

articles.headline: China’s Genetic Research on Ethnic Minorities Sets Off Science Backlash
articles.snippet: Scientists are raising questions about the ethics of studies backed by Chinese surveillance agencies. Prestigious journals are taking action.
articles.abstract: Scientists are raising questions about the ethics of studies backed by Chinese surveillance agencies. Prestigious journals are taking action.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s efforts to study the DNA of the country’s ethnic minorities have incited a growing backlash from the global scientific community, as a number of scientists warn that Beijing could use its growing knowledge to spy on and oppress its people.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: How Google’s Founders Slowly Stepped Away From Their Company
articles.snippet: Larry Page and Sergey Brin became billionaires thanks to the success of Google. But toward the end, they appeared happy to let someone else run it.
articles.abstract: Larry Page and Sergey Brin became billionaires thanks to the success of Google. But toward the end, they appeared happy to let someone else run it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — About a month after Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, Larry Page, the Google co-founder, was summoned along with other prominent tech executives to a meeting at Trump Tower.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Conor Dougherty and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Mocked Abroad and Assailed at Home, Trump Returns to Face Impeachment
articles.snippet: Two days in London on the world stage provided him no respite.
articles.abstract: Two days in London on the world stage provided him no respite.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When times turn tough, presidents can hop on Air Force One to escape the country for a while and stride purposefully across the world stage. But the world stage was not so friendly this week for President Trump, who landed back in Washington on Wednesday night to confront a grim couple of weeks ahead.

articles.headline: Working at Equinox: ‘It’s Very Hunger Games’
articles.snippet: Working for the high-end gym chain seems glamorous, but for many trainers the schedule is unforgiving, the pay low and the turnover high.
articles.abstract: Working for the high-end gym chain seems glamorous, but for many trainers the schedule is unforgiving, the pay low and the turnover high.
articles.lead_paragraph: Equinox, the high-end gym chain, calls its five-story facility on Greenwich Avenue in Manhattan a “fitness mecca.” It features a juice bar and a boxing studio, a eucalyptus steam room and a saltwater lap pool.

articles.headline: Could Tax Increases Speed Up the Economy? Democrats Say Yes
articles.snippet: Led by Elizabeth Warren, presidential candidates and liberal economists are pushing an unorthodox “pro-growth” argument for raising taxes on the rich.
articles.abstract: Led by Elizabeth Warren, presidential candidates and liberal economists are pushing an unorthodox “pro-growth” argument for raising taxes on the rich.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elizabeth Warren is leading a liberal rebellion against a long-held economic view that large tax increases slow economic growth, trying to upend Democratic policymaking in the way supply-side conservatives changed Republican orthodoxy four decades ago.

articles.headline: Pelosi Says House Will Draft Impeachment Charges Against Trump
articles.snippet: The speaker said she was instructing House committee chairmen to move forward with articles of impeachment against President Trump; another hearing is scheduled for Monday.
articles.abstract: The speaker said she was instructing House committee chairmen to move forward with articles of impeachment against President Trump; another hearing is scheduled for Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on Thursday that the House of Representatives would begin drafting impeachment articles against President Trump, pushing ahead with a rapid timetable that could set the stage for a vote before Christmas to charge him with high crimes and misdemeanors.

articles.headline: The Chinese Roots of Italy’s Far-Right Rage
articles.snippet: The country’s new politics are often attributed to anger over migrants. But the story begins decades ago, when China first targeted small textile towns.
articles.abstract: The country’s new politics are often attributed to anger over migrants. But the story begins decades ago, when China first targeted small textile towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRATO, Italy — Like everyone in her family and most of the people in the factories where she labored in this town nurtured by the textile trade, Roberta Travaglini counted herself an unwavering supporter of the political left.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Emma Bubola
